Founded by Pedro Meneses Hoyos on May 17, 1954, it was the first TV station in Chihuahua state, the first Spanish channel in Juarez, El Paso and Las Cruces, and the 3rd TV station outside of Mexico city. From XEJ, many talented locals were projected, who became legends of [[Golden Age of Mexican cinema|Mexican golden era cinema]] and music: [[Germán Valdés|Tin Tan]], [[Lorenzo de Monteclaro]], [[Charro Avitia]], and Alberto Aguilera AKA Adan Luna and/or [[Juan Gabriel]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} Mr. Meneses produced in the early days of television, entertaining programs such "El barco de la illusion", "Doctora Corazon", "Noches Rancheras", "La hora del aficcionado", "Papa Quinito", "[[Niko Liko]]" (the clown) and others. Presently, XEJ still broadcasting from its original studios, at Vicente Guerrero and Constitucion streets; it broadcasts Mexico city's Galavision signal, from 12 pm to 11 pm and still produces its own newscast (Noticinco). Rafael Fitzmaurice Meneses, Grandson of its founder, Pedro Meneses, is now the station's General Director.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} ==Digital television== The digital signal was activated in June 1, 2012. <ref>http://www.rabbitears.info/market.php?request=station_search&callsign=XEJ-TDT</ref> === Digital subchannels === '''XEJ-TDT2''' ''(Branded as '''TVA Televisión Alternativa''')'' is a second digital subchannel of XEJ-TV launched on June 2, 2012.
